com.example.littleync.model

Class User

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.example.littleync.model.User

  • public class User
extends java.lang.Object
    User object with attributes that match what is stored in the users collection of the DB

    • Constructor Detail

      • User

        public User(java.lang.String userName,
            int woodchoppingGearLevel,
            int fishingGearLevel,
            int combatGearLevel,
            int aggregateLevel,
            int wood,
            int fish,
            int gold,
            java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> trades,
            int exp)
        Constructor for the User; only called in sign-up page when we need to initialize a brand new user
        Parameters:
        userName - this User's user name
        woodchoppingGearLevel - woodchopping gear level
        fishingGearLevel - fishing gear level
        combatGearLevel - combar gear level
        aggregateLevel - an aggregate level to indicate how experienced this User is
        wood - wood resource
        fish - fish resource
        gold - gold resource
        trades - list of trade document IDs, which correspond to "trades" collection in DB, each User can have a max of 5 trades at any given time
        exp - this is used to calculate the aggregate level; required exp by level: 50 * level ^ 1.8

      • User

        public User()
        Empty constructor required to automatically parse User document from DB

    • Method Detail

      • writeToDatabaseDirectly

        public void writeToDatabaseDirectly(com.google.firebase.firestore.DocumentReference userDoc)
        Write the selected User object to DB immediately. This is used when we sign up and when we update the seller's User in the DB when trading. We are able to immediately write to DB without doing any intermediate updates since there is no chance for intermediate User attributes to be affected, unlike below.
        Parameters:
        userDoc - the DocumentReference that points to the User of interest; note that this is not always the User that is currently logged in (e.g. while trading)

      • writeToDatabase

        public void writeToDatabase(com.google.firebase.firestore.FirebaseFirestore fs,
                            com.google.firebase.firestore.DocumentReference userDoc,
                            User initialUser)
        Write User object to the DB. We need to also pass in the initial state of the user. This is so that in the case when the User object is locally stored for some task, e.g. fishing or woodchopping, if one of their active trades are accepted, then we need to reflect this properly and not immediately overwrite this trade data. Thus, we need to calculate delta change for our three resources (which are the ones that can be affected by trading), as well as the User trade list. For the User trade list, we need to maintain a purely local newTrades list, then combine that with the most recent read from the DB.
        Parameters:
        userDoc - the DocumentReference object that connects this User object to the DB
        initialUser - a snapshot of the User when initially loaded in

      • requiredExperience

        public int requiredExperience(int level)
        Returns the amount of exp required to get to the next aggregate level; formula to convert exp to aggregate level: 50 * level ^ 1.8
        Parameters:
        level - the current aggregate level
        Returns:
        the amount of exp required for the next aggregate level

      • computeAggregateLevelIndex

        private int computeAggregateLevelIndex()
        Compute the aggregate level from the amount of exp
        Returns:
        the current aggregate level

      • checkNextLevel

        private java.lang.Boolean checkNextLevel()
        Simple check if the aggregate level needs to be updated
        Returns:
        true if level needs to be updated

      • addTrade

        public void addTrade(java.lang.String documentID)
        Adds a trade to the local User object, physically adds to both the current trades list and the newTrades list; we need to ensure the local User object does not have more than 5 trades, but when we write to the DB, we need this separately maintained newTrades list
        Parameters:
        documentID - the documentID that corresponds to the document in the trades collection

      • removeTrade

        public void removeTrade(java.lang.String documentID)
        Remove a trade from this User object
        Parameters:
        documentID - the documentID to remove
